text: The role of shared receptor motifs and common Stat proteins in the generation of cytokine pleiotropy and redundancy by <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-13 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

To understand the molecular bases for cytokine redundancy and pleiotropy , we have compared the Stat proteins activated in peripheral blood lymphocytes ( PBLs ) by cytokines with shared and distinct actions .

<extra_id_0> Interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) rapidly activated <extra_id_0> Stat5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in fresh PBL , and <extra_id_0> Stat3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Stat5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in preactivated PBL .

<extra_id_0> IL-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induced the same complexes as <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a feature explained by the existence of similar tyrosine - phosphorylated motifs in the cytoplasmic domains of <extra_id_0> IL-2R beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-7R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that can serve as docking sites for Stat proteins .

<extra_id_0> IL-13 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Induced the same complexes as <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a finding explained by our studies implicating <extra_id_0> IL-4R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a shared component of the receptors .

These studies demonstrate that a single cytokine can activate different combinations of Stat proteins under different physiological conditions , and also indicate two mechanisms by which distinct cytokines can activate the same Stat protein .
